name: Scylla and Charybdis
title: Greek - Scylla and Charybdis
role: Twin Sea Monsters Guarding the Strait, The Impossible Choice
summary: Scylla and Charybdis are the twin terrors of the strait in Homer's Odyssey, embodying the impossible choice. Scylla is a six-headed monster dwelling in a cliff, snatching sailors from passing ships. Charybdis is a whirlpool that swallows the sea three times daily. Circe advises Odysseus to sail closer to Scylla - losing six men is better than losing the entire ship to Charybdis. The phrase 'between Scylla and Charybdis' has become proverbial for any dilemma with no good option.
description: Scylla, the six-headed monster, and Charybdis, the deadly whirlpool, guard opposite sides of a narrow strait in Homer's Odyssey. Odysseus must choose between them: sailing near Scylla costs six men to her jaws, while Charybdis would swallow the entire ship. This impossible choice has become proverbial.

scylla: Six long necks with six heads
Three rows of teeth in each mouth
charybdis: Swallows the sea three times daily
Spews it back three times daily
Located beneath a fig tree on a cliff

homeric_context.role_in_epic: The ultimate impossible choice - lose some men or lose all

the_episode.circes_advice: Sail closer to Scylla; losing six men is better than losing all to Charybdis
the_episode.the_passage: Odysseus focuses the crew on Charybdis while Scylla snatches six men
the_episode.odysseus_helpless: He can do nothing but watch as his men are devoured
the_episode.second_encounter: After Thrinacia disaster, Odysseus alone drifts back; clings to fig tree above Charybdis until his mast resurfaces

the_choice.scylla: Lose six men to her six heads
the_choice.charybdis: Lose the entire ship and crew
the_choice.circes_advice: Always choose Scylla - some loss is better than total destruction

proverbial_use.meaning: Between Scylla and Charybdis means facing two dangers where avoiding one increases risk from the other
proverbial_use.modern_equivalent: Between a rock and a hard place
proverbial_use.significance: One of the most enduring metaphors from Greek mythology

scylla_origin: Once a beautiful nymph, transformed by Circe (in later tradition)
charybdis_origin: Daughter of Poseidon and Gaia, punished by Zeus (in later tradition)
victims: Six of Odysseus's men snatched by Scylla
Countless other sailors over the ages
